ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: modern technology in the world, how it applies to yale specifically and also otherwise, presentation skills, researching skills

I learned a lot about various modern technological trends particularly in the environment sphere of influence. A main focus of the class was about learning to ask the right question, and many historical and modern examples of this questioning mindset were given through presentation throughout the class.
A better understanding of the relation between technology, the environment, and public policy.
I gained insight into the history and applications of various forms of energy, transportation, and communication.
I got an introductory level understanding of a variety of technologies and a chill classroom experience that I didn't get in any other course this year.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: easy and clear with homework/midterm/presentation expectations, grading not difficult at all. weaknesses: lectures can get a bit monotone at times.

A strength of this course is the quantity and quality of the guest speakers, as they all introduced and explained different technologies or happenings in their field of study which was very interesting. A weakness of this course is the lecture style of presentation, which allows little room for discussion and analysis with students primarily just sitting in their seats listening during class. Additionally, all of the homework and midterm only related to the first half of the semester, with the information learned in the second half seeming less important or more ineffectual given there were never any assignments concerning those lectures.
Lectures could be a bit more interactive. I loved the guest lecturers, definitely the best part of the course.
One of the weaknesses was that the same material was being taught again and again. And because it was an intro course for non-science majors, there wasnt a deep look into the science material.
The strengths are that all lecture notes are available in multiple (both print and digital) forms, allowing students to review what they have learned.

I think the strengths of the class are in its small workload and its focus on students enjoying the material. I think the weaknesses were in the engagement of the lectures and the lack of in-depth knowledge acquired by taking the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! An easy way to knock out a science credit in first/second semester itself

I would recommend this course as it is not difficult and does not carry a large workload at all, while you will still get to learn some interesting facts and have a greater knowledge of the scientific process for many modern and future technologies.
I'd recommend it to a non-science major interested in a broader understanding of science.
Yes. It was interesting, exposing me to a variety of technological concepts that will inform future societal developments.

I think if the student wants a laid-back class that introduces them to a variety of topics, I would encourage them to take it. If they had a hard time paying attention to long lectures or wanted a thorough or in-depth understanding of the topics, I would not recommend it.
